articles.headline: Honda Fined for Violations of Safety Law
articles.snippet: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration fined Honda $35 million in each of two civil penalties, the most levied against a carmaker at a time.
articles.abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration fined Honda $35 million in each of two civil penalties, the most levied against a carmaker at a time.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sharp escalation of penalties against automakers that skirt safety laws, the nation’s top auto safety agency has fined Honda Motor a record $70 million for grossly underreporting fatal accidents and injuries to the government, regulators said on Thursday.

articles.headline: Those Who Nailed 2014 See Volatility This Year
articles.snippet: A survey of investment professionals whose forecasts proved accurate in 2014 indicates a roller-coaster ride for stocks, bonds and oil prices.
articles.abstract: A survey of investment professionals whose forecasts proved accurate in 2014 indicates a roller-coaster ride for stocks, bonds and oil prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volatility will be the new normal in 2015.

articles.headline: Al Qaeda Trained Suspect in Paris Terror Attack, Official Says
articles.snippet: Saïd Kouachi, 34, one of the two brothers suspected of killing 12 people at a newspaper, spent “a few months” with an Al Qaeda affiliate in Yemen, a U.S. official said.
articles.abstract: Saïd Kouachi, 34, one of the two brothers suspected of killing 12 people at a newspaper, spent “a few months” with an Al Qaeda affiliate in Yemen, a U.S. official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the two brothers suspected of killing 12 people at a satirical newspaper in Paris traveled to Yemen in 2011 and received terrorist training from Al Qaeda’s affiliate there before returning to France, a senior American official said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Michael S. Schmidt and Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: DuPont Finds Itself a Target of Activist Nelson Peltz
articles.snippet: The activist investor has nominated four director candidates, escalating his campaign to break up the chemical maker.
articles.abstract: The activist investor has nominated four director candidates, escalating his campaign to break up the chemical maker.
articles.lead_paragraph: DuPont is about to face one of the biggest challenges in its two centuries as an industrial powerhouse: a fight with one of Wall Street’s most prominent activist investors over its board.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Bombardier’s CSeries Gamble Is Facing Longer Odds
articles.snippet: The company is making an innovative smaller airliner that has been plagued by so many delays that competitors have had time to create similar versions.
articles.abstract: The company is making an innovative smaller airliner that has been plagued by so many delays that competitors have had time to create similar versions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — If all had gone according to plan, Bombardier’s direct challenge to the Boeing 737, the world’s best-selling commercial plane, would be approaching its second year in service. Instead, Bombardier’s grand plan for a new plane, the CSeries airliner, has faced myriad delays.

articles.headline: Debt Buyer Faces Fine and Loss of Thousands of Court Judgments
articles.snippet: A company that buys consumer debt is expected to vacate 4,500 court judgments over concerns that its debt collection lawsuits were riddled with errors and fabrications.
articles.abstract: A company that buys consumer debt is expected to vacate 4,500 court judgments over concerns that its debt collection lawsuits were riddled with errors and fabrications.
articles.lead_paragraph: In courtrooms across New York State, lawsuits poured in by the hundreds as if manufactured on an assembly line. Some included generic testimony, others relied on bogus affidavits, churned out so rapidly that they were seldom viewed for accuracy.

articles.headline: Raising Questions Within Islam After France Shooting
articles.snippet: Muslims are debating why their religion is so often cited as a cause for violence and bloodshed.
articles.abstract: Muslims are debating why their religion is so often cited as a cause for violence and bloodshed.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Islamist extremists behead Western journalists in Syria, massacre thousands of Iraqis, murder 132 Pakistani schoolchildren, kill a Canadian soldier and take hostage cafe patrons in Australia. Now, two gunmen have massacred a dozen people in the office of a Paris newspaper.

articles.headline: French Police Storm Hostage Sites, Killing Gunmen
articles.snippet: The police killed two brothers who had links to Al Qaeda in Yemen and were suspected in the massacre at a Paris newspaper office. In a nearly simultaneous raid, officers also killed an alleged associate of the brothers who had held hostages in a k...
articles.abstract: The police killed two brothers who had links to Al Qaeda in Yemen and were suspected in the massacre at a Paris newspaper office. In a nearly simultaneous raid, officers also killed an alleged associate of the brothers who had held hostages in a kosher supermarket.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French police killed three terrorists on Friday in raids, ending three days of bloodshed that shook a nation struggling with Islamic extremists.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Dan Bilefsky

articles.headline: Honda in Japan Distances Itself From Fine on U.S. Subsidiary
articles.snippet: A $70 million fine imposed on Honda by the United States was treated in Japan like an American problem for what has become a highly American company.
articles.abstract: A $70 million fine imposed on Honda by the United States was treated in Japan like an American problem for what has become a highly American company.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A record $70 million fine imposed on Honda Motor by safety regulators in the United States was being treated in Japan like a mildly intriguing piece of foreign news: an American problem for what has become, in many ways, a highly American company.

articles.headline: Job Growth Fails to Help Paychecks of Workers
articles.snippet: The unemployment rate fell to its lowest level since June 2008, but average hourly earnings fell 0.2 percent, erasing some of the gains of last month.
articles.abstract: The unemployment rate fell to its lowest level since June 2008, but average hourly earnings fell 0.2 percent, erasing some of the gains of last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s economy is entering 2015 in its best shape since the recession, but the improving job market has so far failed to help most Americans earn significantly more at work.

articles.headline: Obama Facing Rising Pressure on Keystone Oil Pipeline
articles.snippet: After the Nebraska Supreme Court cleared the way for construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, the House voted, 266 to 153, approving of the project.
articles.abstract: After the Nebraska Supreme Court cleared the way for construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, the House voted, 266 to 153, approving of the project.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama came under new pressure on Friday to make a decision on the Keystone XL oil pipeline as the Nebraska Supreme Court cleared the way for its construction through the state and the House passed a bill to approve the project.
articles.byline: By Coral Davenport and Mitch Smith
